name: Linux Kernel
facts: Created by Linus Torvalds while he was a student at the University of Helsinki
Initially developed as a free alternative to the MINIX operating system
First announced on August 25, 1991, in a Usenet posting
Version 1.0 was released in March 1994, supporting only single-processor i386 systems

children.name: Clear Linux
facts: Developed by Intel specifically optimized for Intel hardware
Designed for high performance in cloud and container environments
Uses a unique bundle-based package management system
Implements aggressive performance optimizations and security mitigations

children.name: Solus
facts: Originally started as SolusOS (Debian-based) but was later rebuilt from scratch
Developed the Budgie desktop environment, which is now also available on other distributions
Uses the eopkg package management system derived from PiSi
Follows a curated rolling release model that balances stability and up-to-date software

children.name: SUSE Linux
facts: Originally a German translation of Slackware
Became the first distribution with a YaST graphical installer
Split into openSUSE (community) and SUSE Linux Enterprise (commercial) in 2005

children.name: openSUSE
facts: Community-driven version of SUSE Linux
Offers both Leap (regular release) and Tumbleweed (rolling release) versions
Known for its powerful YaST configuration tool and KDE integration

children.name: Slackware
facts: One of the oldest Linux distributions still in active development
Known for its simplicity and UNIX-like design philosophy

children.name: Slax
facts: Designed to run from USB drives or CD-ROMs without installation
Uses a modular approach allowing easy customization

children.name: Salix
facts: Fully compatible with Slackware but more user-friendly
Follows a 'one application per task' philosophy to reduce bloat

children.name: Zenwalk
facts: Aims to be a modern, fast, and lightweight Slackware-based distribution
Optimized for desktop usage with a single application per task approach

children.name: Debian
facts: Known for its commitment to free software principles
Uses one of the most comprehensive package management systems (APT)

children.name: Deepin
facts: Developed in China with a focus on elegant design and user experience
Features the Deepin Desktop Environment (DDE)
Known for its custom applications and polished look

children.name: Parrot OS
facts: Designed for security experts, developers, and privacy-conscious users
Includes tools for penetration testing, forensics, and development
Lightweight and based on Debian

children.name: Ubuntu
facts: Named after the African philosophy of 'Ubuntu' meaning 'humanity to others'
Releases new versions every 6 months with Long Term Support (LTS) versions every 2 years

children.name: Linux Mint
facts: Known for its Cinnamon desktop environment, which preserves a traditional desktop experience
Focuses on out-of-the-box usability with pre-installed codecs and drivers
Consistently ranked as one of the most popular Linux distributions for desktop users

children.name: Feren OS
facts: Based on Linux Mint/Ubuntu with a focus on providing a familiar experience for Windows users
Features a customized KDE Plasma desktop environment with a Windows-like layout
Includes a theme manager for easy customization of the desktop appearance
Comes with a migration tool to help users transition from Windows

children.name: Zorin OS
facts: Designed to look and feel familiar to Windows users transitioning to Linux
Offers a unique 'Zorin Appearance' app to switch between different desktop layouts
Available in free Core edition and paid Pro edition with additional features

children.name: Elementary OS
facts: Known for its macOS-inspired design and user interface
Developed its own desktop environment called Pantheon
Focuses on a 'pay-what-you-want' funding model for sustainable open source development

children.name: Pop!_OS
facts: Developed by computer manufacturer System76
Optimized for graphics and compute workflows with specialized support for NVIDIA GPUs
Features unique window tiling and keyboard navigation system

children.name: Kubuntu
facts: Official Ubuntu flavor featuring the KDE Plasma desktop environment
Combines Ubuntu's infrastructure with KDE's applications and technologies
Offers a more customizable desktop experience compared to standard Ubuntu

children.name: Lubuntu
facts: Official Ubuntu flavor featuring the lightweight LXQt desktop environment
Designed for older computers with limited resources
Focuses on speed and energy-efficiency while maintaining usability

children.name: Xubuntu
facts: Official Ubuntu flavor featuring the Xfce desktop environment
Balances performance and features for a responsive system
Provides a traditional desktop experience with modern capabilities

children.name: Ubuntu MATE
facts: Official Ubuntu flavor featuring the MATE desktop environment
Continues the traditional GNOME 2 desktop experience
Focuses on usability and performance while maintaining familiarity

children.name: Ubuntu Budgie
facts: Official Ubuntu flavor featuring the Budgie desktop environment
Provides a modern, simplified desktop experience
Developed in collaboration with the Solus project

children.name: KDE Neon
facts: Combines an Ubuntu LTS base with the latest KDE Plasma desktop
Developed by KDE to showcase the latest KDE technologies
Not an official Ubuntu flavor but uses Ubuntu as its foundation

children.name: Ubuntu Studio
facts: Official Ubuntu flavor focused on multimedia creation
Includes specialized audio, video, and graphics applications
Features a low-latency kernel optimized for audio production

children.name: Devuan
facts: Created as a fork of Debian to avoid the systemd init system
Named as a play on 'Debian' with 'dev' replacing 'deb' (developers taking back control)
Focuses on init system freedom and choice

children.name: Kali Linux
facts: Developed by Offensive Security as a successor to BackTrack
Includes hundreds of pre-installed tools for security testing and digital forensics
Used extensively by cybersecurity professionals and ethical hackers

children.name: MX Linux
facts: Collaboration between the antiX and former MEPIS Linux communities
Combines lightweight efficiency with elegant and user-friendly design
Consistently ranked as one of the most popular distributions on DistroWatch

children.name: Raspberry Pi OS
facts: Formerly known as Raspbian, optimized for Raspberry Pi hardware
Designed for educational purposes and IoT projects
Based on Debian with modifications for ARM architecture
Developed by the Raspberry Pi Foundation to support their hardware platform

children.name: Red Hat Linux
facts: One of the first commercially successful Linux companies
Evolved into Red Hat Enterprise Linux (RHEL), a paid enterprise distribution with long-term support
Red Hat was acquired by IBM in 2019 for $34 billion, one of the largest software acquisitions in history

children.name: Red Hat Enterprise Linux
facts: Commercial, enterprise-grade Linux distribution with professional support
Features long lifecycles and stability for business environments
Serves as the foundation for many other enterprise Linux distributions

children.name: Fedora
facts: Serves as the upstream testing ground for Red Hat Enterprise Linux
Known for adopting new technologies early, like Wayland and systemd
Sponsored by Red Hat but developed by a community of volunteers
Releases new versions approximately every 6 months

children.name: CentOS
facts: Originally a community rebuild of Red Hat Enterprise Linux source code
In 2020, shifted to CentOS Stream, which serves as the upstream for RHEL rather than a downstream clone
The original CentOS project was acquired by Red Hat in 2014

children.name: CentOS Stream
facts: Rolling preview of Red Hat Enterprise Linux with a community focus
Serves as the upstream development platform for future RHEL releases
Provides a middle ground between Fedora and RHEL in terms of stability and cutting-edge features

children.name: Rocky Linux
facts: Created by Gregory Kurtzer, the original founder of CentOS
Developed in response to the CentOS project's shift to CentOS Stream
Aims to be a 100% bug-for-bug compatible with Red Hat Enterprise Linux

children.name: AlmaLinux
facts: Developed by CloudLinux as a response to the CentOS Stream shift
Designed as a stable, production-ready drop-in replacement for CentOS
Governed by a non-profit organization with community involvement

children.name: Gentoo Linux
facts: Known for its source-based package management system called Portage
Allows users to optimize software for their specific hardware
Named after the fast-swimming Gentoo penguin species
Emphasizes user choice and control over the system

children.name: Calculate Linux
facts: Gentoo-based distribution developed in Russia
Designed for easy installation and use in corporate environments
Provides ready-to-use desktop and server solutions

children.name: Funtoo Linux
facts: Created by Daniel Robbins, the original founder of Gentoo
Focuses on performance improvements and new features
Uses Git for its Portage tree instead of rsync

children.name: Sabayon Linux
facts: Aims to provide an easy-to-use, out-of-the-box Gentoo experience
Offers binary package support for faster installation
Focuses on multimedia and gaming support

children.name: NixOS
facts: Uses the Nix package manager with a purely functional deployment model
Allows for reliable system upgrades and rollbacks
Enables multiple versions of packages to coexist on the same system
Configuration is described in a declarative language

children.name: home-manager
facts: Not a full distribution but a tool to manage user environments using Nix
Allows declarative configuration of user dotfiles and packages
Can be used on any Linux distribution with Nix installed

children.name: Void Linux
facts: Independent distribution not based on any other Linux distribution
Offers choice between musl libc and glibc
Uses the XBPS package manager and runit init system instead of systemd
Features a rolling release model with a focus on stability

children.name: Alpine Linux
facts: Designed to be small, simple, and secure
Uses musl libc and busybox instead of GNU components
Extremely popular as a base for Docker containers
Uses OpenRC as its init system instead of systemd

children.name: postmarketOS
facts: Aims to give smartphones a longer life by bringing Linux to them
Based on Alpine Linux with modifications for mobile devices
Supports a wide range of old and new mobile devices

children.name: Arch Linux
facts: Famous for its 'Keep It Simple, Stupid' (KISS) philosophy and minimalist approach
Uses a rolling release model where packages are continuously updated rather than in major version releases
Designed for users who want full control over their system configuration

children.name: Manjaro
facts: Makes Arch Linux more accessible with a user-friendly installer and pre-configured desktop environments
Holds packages for additional testing before release, unlike Arch's immediate updates

children.name: EndeavourOS
facts: Created as a spiritual successor to Antergos (another user-friendly Arch-based distro)
Aims to be closer to vanilla Arch while still providing an easy installation process

children.name: ArcoLinux
facts: Educational Arch-based distribution with multiple desktop options
Focuses on teaching users about Arch Linux through a learning path
Offers several editions with different levels of pre-configuration

children.name: Garuda Linux
facts: Focuses on performance, gaming, and visual appeal
Ships with Btrfs filesystem and advanced snapshots by default
Offers several desktop environments and a rolling release model

children.name: Puppy Linux
facts: Designed to run entirely in RAM for speed and responsiveness
Can run from USB drives or CD-ROMs without installation
Extremely small footprint, often under 300MB
Includes a variety of applications despite its small size

children.name: Porteus
facts: Modular Slackware-based live distribution
Designed to be fast, portable, and lightweight
Uses a modular approach allowing easy customization
Can be booted from various media including USB, CD, or hard drive

children.name: Tiny Core Linux
facts: One of the smallest Linux distributions with a graphical interface
Core system is only about 16MB in size
Based on a modular design where users add only what they need
Designed to run entirely in RAM for speed and minimal disk usage

children.name: Tails
facts: The Amnesic Incognito Live System designed for privacy and anonymity
Routes all internet traffic through the Tor network
Leaves no digital footprint on the host computer
Designed to be booted as a live system from USB or DVD

children.name: Qubes OS
facts: Security-focused desktop operating system that uses virtualization for compartmentalization
Isolates different activities in separate virtual machines (qubes)
Endorsed by privacy advocates including Edward Snowden
Implements the principle of security by isolation
